title: Lesson 2: Who You Are - Identity in Jesus the Son
description: You are made in the image of God and adopted through Jesus the Son - the second person of the Trinity. This lesson roots your identity not in performance or approval but in the finished work of Christ, who restores the image that sin cracked and makes you a full child of the Father.

blocks.text: The first five lessons of this course have been building a foundation - the Greatest Commandment, loving others, the reality of sin, the grace of justification, and the response of faith and repentance. All of that theology has been pointing somewhere: to a new identity. Before we can talk about how to live, we need to settle who you are.
The Search That Never Ends

A.W. Tozer once wrote, "What comes into our minds when we think about God is the most important thing about us." That is a striking claim - not what you do, not what you have accomplished, but what you think about God. He was pointing to something deep: the way we see God shapes the way we see ourselves, and the way we see ourselves shapes everything else.

If you look honestly at human life, one pattern shows up everywhere. People are searching. For significance. For belonging. For something that will finally feel like enough. We try relationships, achievements, experiences, and none of them quite deliver. We feel it in the quiet moments - the nagging sense that we were made for something more than what we have found.
That restlessness is not a malfunction. It is a clue. You were made for something specific, and until you find it, nothing else will fully satisfy.
What is man that you are mindful of him, and the son of man that you care for him? Yet you have made him a little lower than the heavenly beings and crowned him with glory and honor.
6.1 - What comes to mind when you think about who God is? And honestly, what does that reveal about how you see yourself?
Made to Reflect

The first pages of Scripture make a claim that changes everything: you are made in the image of God. This is not just a theological footnote. It is the most foundational truth about every human being who has ever lived.
So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them.

To be an image-bearer means you were designed to display, reflect, and point people toward who God is. Think of it like a mirror set at a 45-degree angle. When people look at you - at your love, your patience, your honesty, your care - they are meant to catch a glimpse of the God who made you. You are not just a person living a life. You are a walking, breathing reflection of the One who holds all things together.
That is the original design. And it explains why there is such deep joy when we live close to God. We are most fully ourselves when we are most fully reflecting Him.
6.2 - What does it mean to you personally that you were made to reflect God? How does that change the way you see your ordinary, everyday life?
The Image We Cracked

But we already know from Lesson 3 what happened. The first humans turned away from God, and in doing so they cracked the mirror. The image was not destroyed - you still bear it, every human does - but it was distorted. Instead of reflecting God's glory outward, we turned inward. We began chasing the glory that used to be ours through God by looking for it in other places.

Approval. Status. Control. Comfort. Beauty. Performance. These are not evil things in themselves. But we have a way of making them into the thing that defines us - the thing we cannot lose without losing ourselves. And none of them are big enough to hold the weight of an identity. They all eventually crack under the pressure.

This is why performance-based Christianity is so exhausting. When you are trying to earn your standing with God, you are essentially trying to manufacture what only He can give. The treadmill never stops. There is always one more thing to do, one more standard to reach, one more reason to doubt whether you are really enough.
6.3 - Where in your own life have you looked for significance, approval, or belonging in things that could not actually deliver it? What did that feel like?
Adopted, Not Just Forgiven

Here is what the gospel does with your identity - and it goes further than most people realize. When Jesus brings you back to God, He does not just clear your record. He changes your name. You are not simply a forgiven sinner. You are an adopted child.
See what kind of love the Father has given to us, that we should be called children of God; and so we are.
He predestined us for adoption to himself as sons through Jesus Christ, according to the purpose of his will.

John stops to marvel at this. "See what kind of love" - as if he is still stunned by it after years of thinking about it. The love that makes you a child of God is not ordinary love. It is the kind that requires you to pause and really look at it.

Adoption in the ancient world meant full legal standing in the family. Not a second-tier member, not a guest. A son. A daughter. With all the rights, belonging, and inheritance that came with it. That is the language the New Testament uses for what God has done for you. And because the mirror is being restored through Christ, as you grow closer to Him, you increasingly reflect what you were always designed to reflect.
And we all, with unveiled face, beholding the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from one degree of glory to another. For this comes from the Lord who is the Spirit.

6.4 - What is the difference between living as a forgiven sinner trying to do better versus living as an adopted child who is already fully loved? What would shift in your daily life if you really believed the second one?
The Satisfied Child

When your identity is settled in God, something interesting happens. You stop needing the world to tell you who you are. You stop performing for approval because you already have it. You stop chasing counterfeit glories because you have access to the real one.

John Piper describes this as Christian Hedonism - the idea that God is most glorified in us when we are most satisfied in Him. A satisfied child does not strain and strive. A satisfied child lives from a full place, not an empty one. And that fullness naturally overflows. When you are genuinely satisfied in God, you reflect His image more clearly to the people around you - not because you are trying harder, but because you are drawing from the right source.

Think of one person in your life right now - a family member, a coworker, a neighbor. That person is an image-bearer too, whether they know it or not. How you treat them is a reflection of how you understand who God is. The way you love, listen, forgive, and serve is either pointing them toward the Father or it is not.
6.5 - In which relationships or situations are you struggling to reflect Jesus right now? What do you think is getting in the way?
6.6 - What would it look like for you to be so satisfied in God this week that it naturally changed how you showed up for the people around you? Write one specific, concrete picture.
Closing Reflections
What is one key thing you learned from this lesson?
What is one step you are going to take this week?
What is a prayer request for this week?
